The argument is in the form of a conditional statement, specifically a contrapositive argument. In a contrapositive argument, if the original conditional statement is 'If P then Q', the contrapositive statement is 'If not Q then not P'.

In this case, the original conditional statement is 'If Joe went to the park, then Lucy went to the zoo'. The contrapositive statement would be 'If Lucy did not go to the zoo, then Joe did not go to the park'.

However, the conclusion of the argument is 'Joe did not go to the park', which is not the same as the contrapositive statement. Therefore, the argument is not logically valid based on the principles of contrapositive reasoning.
